repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Third School Improvement
            (FUNDESCOLA IIIA) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third School Improvement
            (FUNDESCOLA IIIA) Project for Brazil were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, risks to development outcome
            were negligible to low, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the FUNDESCOLA
            IIIA had a clear strategy for product development, which
            ranged from design to evaluation and dissemination of
            products. The importance of testing and evaluating products
            proved to be essential in the scaling up of the project. In
            addition, the dissemination of results within Brazil and
            beyond served to galvanize support around a school-based
            strategy to improve quality, efficiency and learning
            outcomes. Indeed, the federal government acknowledged the
            proven track record of the FUNDESCOLA products was among the
            factors that motivated them to scale up the implementation
            of some of the products within the umbrella of the national
            School Development Plan (PDE). The FUNDESCOLA approach to
            strategic planning uses a bottom-up framework rather than a
            top-down approach. This approach is central to the
            successful implementation of the project given that behavior
            change is more likely to take place when there is genuine
            self-reflection on issues and local leadership to plan a way
            forward to make changes. The FUNDESCOLA IIIA places the
            responsibility on individual schools to identify their needs
            and draft their own solutions, while providing products,
            tool and reference materials to assist individual schools or
            to technical staff providing support. The approach has now
            taken root in Brazil and has served to galvanize federal
            government support around it to ensure future programs are
            guided by a bottom-up principle.

Brazil - Third School Improvement
            (FUNDESCOLA IIIA) Project

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Third School Improvement Project :
            proposed amendment to the Loan Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed amendment would adjust the
            design of the Third School Improvement Project, adapting to
            the Government needs to improve public education in the
            North, Northeast and Center-West regions of Brazil, through
            the financing of school rehabilitation, as well as
            construction of new schools. As requested by the Government,
            the amendment to the Loan Agreement will include a new
            subcomponent to support the rehabilitation and construction
            of schools. Consequently, the following changes will apply:
            a) inclusion of category of works in Schedule 1 of the Loan
            Agreement; 2) inclusion of National Competitive Bidding-NCB-
            procurement method to contract works; and, 3) reallocation
            of loan proceeds among categories to support this new
            financing. These changes are reflected in Schedule I to the
            Amendment, attached herewith. The core of the proposed
            amendment is to adjust the Project in order to ensure it
            will achieve its objectives. The proposed Loan amendment
            complies with the Articles of Agreement, and it is thus
            recommended for approval.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Third School Improvement
            (FUNDESCOLA IIIA) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third School Improvement (FUNDESCOLA
            IIIA) Project for Brazil objective is to contribute to the
            Ministry of Education's goal of ensuring that children
            from the poorest regions of Brazil-the Northeast, North, and
            Central-West states--can successfully complete the eighth
            grade, the final year of the compulsory
            "fundamental" cycle. This environmental assessment
            (EA) report evaluated environmental and social potential
            impacts that will develop during construction of school
            buildings, as follows : reallocation of project affected
            peoples (PAPs); affects on cultural, historical and
            archeological sites; erosion; vegetation; surface water
            drainage; and dust, noise, air, and water quality. Some of
            the mitigation measures are : when object of archeological
            and historical value are found work must stop an designated
            authorities be notified for appropriate follow-up; land
            clearing for construction will be kept to a minimum;
            adequate methods for the collection of construction waste
            and delivery to designated landfills/dumpsites; proper
            disposal of industrial and solid wastes; replanting of
            vegetation after completion of construction; adopt proper
            protection measures to avoid erosion; enforce an environment
            quality assurance system approved by the Secretarias
            Estaduais; trucks leaving construction site must not be
            overloaded, and covered with plastic; ensure vehicles are
            properly serviced to minimized noise and exhaust gas
            emission; ensure use of safety measures when handling
            machinery; develop an emergency plan to respond to injuries;
            and finally, provide health, medical and social assistance
            to PAPs.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Fundescola IIIA (Third School
            Improvement) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fundescola III project is the third
            step in Brazil's ten-year Fundescola School Improvement
            Program. It is to help the Ministry of Education improve
            Brazil's education performance by assisting the states
            and municipalities in the poorest regions of the country,
            the northeast, north, and center-west reduce the educational
            inequalities in their systems, and increase the
            effectiveness of their schools so that all children in these
            regions can successfully complete the eighth grade, the
            final year of the compulsory "fundamental" cycle.
            Fundescola III helps local governments integrate school
            improvement reforms into their structures and routines.
            There are four project components. The first provides some
            additional assistance to schools that had begun to introduce
            Fundescola's schooling improvement reforms consolidate
            these reforms under the responsibility and support of their
            Secretariats of Education. Second, the project will help
            hundreds of local governments expand these reforms into
            thousands of additional schools. Third, the project will
            develop and use a new set of teaching/learning models, in
            addition to Escola Ativa and Gestar, for diverse types of
            schools and population groups. Finally, Fundescola III
            builds the capacity of local governments to support
            continuous improvement in schooling quality, and promote the
            financial, administrative, and managerial permanence of
            these reforms. Fundescola III will be implemented in two
            phases, this being the first phase.
